title: Jeremy Allen White Recreates His Viral Calvin Klein Ad During Shirtless Beach Day
description: The ‘Bear’ actor showed off his impressive physique during the outing.
content:
Jeremy Allen White Recreates His Viral Calvin Klein Ad During Shirtless Beach Day originally appeared on Parade.

Jeremy Allen White flaunted his assets in a look reminiscent of his viral Calvin Klein ad campaign.

The Bear star, 34, enjoyed a day at the beach on Long Island in New York in photos published by TMZ on Monday, August 11. He sported a pair of white swim trunks, showing off his tattoos and muscles while shirtless. The actor was all smiles strolling along the sand and drying off after a dip in the water.

White’s beach day ensemble resembles the white boxer briefs he wore in his headline-making January 2024 Calvin Klein ad. At the time, he left little to the imagination in the fitted underwear, posing with his abs on full display. Fans ultimately went wild for the campaign.

“It’s been a weird couple of days,” White said at the 2024 Golden Globe Awards later that month of the attention surrounding the photo shoot. “It is bizarre doing a Calvin Klein ad and now it is even more bizarre having had it come out. But everything feels OK for now.”

🎬 SIGN UP for Parade's Daily newsletter to get the latest pop culture news & celebrity interviews delivered right to your inbox 🎬

During a June appearance on The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon, White reflected on seeing his Calvin Klein ad on a billboard in New York City.

“It was fresh up for maybe, like, 30 minutes or an hour,” he recalled. “And it was, like, this very beautiful, private moment I had with myself.”

“And before the whole world, you know,” White added before Fallon chimed in, “Their private moments with you.”

Despite the campaign being a huge hit, White revealed in an August 2024 GQ interview that he had his apprehensions about it.

“I felt so insecure leading up to the shoot itself, and it felt kind of crazy,” he explained. “Acting on film or TV and then doing these sort of campaigns or photo shoots, there’s such a big difference — because in film and TV, your job is to sort of forget the camera is there, and then with these sort of shoots, your partner is sort of the photographer and the camera. And so I was concerned about making that work.”

And so I was concerned about making that work.”

It’s late August and Jeremy Allen White is currently in Los Angeles, but the native New Yorker is thinking about summer back in his hometown.
“It is tough in the summer in New York, but it is my favorite,” White told me by phone last week. “I know I'm not alone in that, but I don't think there's many of us. It's my favorite time of year in New York.”
Last year, the Emmy-winning actor shot his first Calvin Klein underwear campaign way up on a Manhattan rooftop, posing in his skivvies against the skyline. Today he’s back for round two—and this time, he’s wearing the brand’s latest fall-winter 2024 collection in sunny LA, in a new poolside portfolio photographed by Mert Alas. Aside from the West Coast locale, the main distinction from the first campaign is that White is now actually wearing jeans.
Ahead of the new launch, White and I chatted about Carmy’s style on The Bear, Bruce Springsteen’s denim legacy, and how he felt about beating Pharrell in GQ’s 2023 Most Stylish Man of the Year tournament.
Jeremy Allen White: Yeah, I mean, yeah…I think it did what it was supposed to do. I felt so insecure leading up to the shoot itself, and it felt kind of crazy. Acting on film or TV and then doing these sort of campaigns or photo shoots, there's such a big difference—because in film and TV, your job is to sort of forget the camera is there, and then with these sort of shoots, your partner is sort of the photographer and the camera. And so I was concerned about making that work.
But yeah, it felt really special. I was in New York when the first campaign went up. When they put the billboard up on Houston, I woke up early that morning and I went with a buddy of mine who brought his camera and took it in before the public took it in. And that felt really wonderful and intimate, and like an achievement. It was still just mine in a really nice way. And then everybody else saw it in the weeks to come. For the most part people were excited about it, and that was cool and surprising. I mean, like so many things in my life right now, they're all very cool and surprising. [Laughs.]
I'm very much a jeans guy. You can say that, yeah.
Comfort is really important, and durability—I like to be able to wear pretty much the same jeans over and over again. I sort of cycle with clothing: I'll kind of just wear generally the same thing or at least a variation of five or six different pieces for a month or even two months. In terms of these standard straight jeans, there is something really sort of classic and elegant, no matter what is trending in the world of pants or denim, I feel like a straight leg with boots is always going to look cool.
I also wore a lot of denim-on-denim for this campaign. Calvin has this really beautiful denim shirt that I wore buttoned down, and a really beautiful denim jacket as well. I don't care what people say—I think denim-on-denim is always going to look cool. We did that shoot in April and then [denim-on-denim] became my summer evening staple. It was a lot of denim button-downs and jeans.
Bruce Springsteen is—I mean this in the very best way—he's a guy. He's a jeans and T-shirt kind of guy. It was exciting to know going into this thing that we had at least that in common.
I'm really lucky that there's sort of a team of folks now in place to help young actors portray rock stars. [Laughs.] I've got a really talented group of people helping me train vocally, musically, to get ready for this thing. I'm also really lucky [that] Bruce is really supportive of the film, and so I've had some access to him and he's just the greatest guy. Also, there's just so much footage. It's really great to go down a YouTube rabbit hole and find him at all these different periods in his life and be able to listen to his speaking voice as well as his singing voice. That's kind of been the deal, just listening to him a lot and watching him a lot. It's been really fun preparing.
I'm not a fashion guy really. Chris [Storer], our showrunner, is very in the know, and Matty [Matheson, a real-life chef who plays handyman Neil Fak in the series] really follows a lot of the stuff and is a very stylish guy. I think Carmy's interest in fashion came from [the idea that] a lot of chefs—a lot of chefs that Matty knows, Matty himself, a lot of chefs that Courtney, Chris's sister, knows—they're also interested in fashion, or they're interested in design. Carmy is interested in fashion because that was just something that people found true of the world of restaurants.
For me, when we meet Carmy in the first season, if he had an interest in fashion, his brain certainly didn't have room to focus on that, or that wasn't a place he was able to express himself in the fashion world or what he was wearing. We needed to find something that was kind of a uniform. I guess, in a sense, Carmy's uniform of work pants and a T-shirt is more my—Jeremy's—style. In that sense, our styles sort of bled together.
I remember.
[Laughing] I was like, “You guys need to stop bullying me. This isn't funny. Get me out of there.”
I know, and it still felt like bullying. [Laughs.] But no, I do recall that. It was really nice. But yeah, it's like I said, comfort and [knowing] what looks good on you, like the silhouette, or how a shirt fits your shoulders, or where jeans sit on your waist, the hem of denim and where that falls on your boot or your sneaker. It's just little things, and it's just about the silhouette, and what makes you feel confident and comfortable.
I'm so lucky that I have Calvin making these sorts of decisions, and then I go in and I kind of just say, “Well, this feels more comfortable to me, this feels less comfortable.” The Golden Globes suit they made me was so beautiful and timeless, and then of course we messed around with a couple different versions of sheerness of an open shirt, which was a bit more of a modern addition to otherwise pretty timeless suiting.
But even though the suiting was comfortable, it was loose. What I really enjoy seeing in men's suiting in particular is: Does somebody look comfortable? Does it look effortless? Does it look easy? If a suit is well-made and structured to your body, it helps you feel more confident and empowered and effortless and cool, ultimately. They did such a beautiful job with that suit.
Aww, well…I don't want to say worry less about what you look like or what the suit looks like, but yeah, if you feel comfortable, it's going to look cooler.
